description: Borrowed from Ecclesiastical Latin temporāle, substantivisation of temporālis (“of or pertaining to time”).

entries.meaning: (Roman Catholicism) A cycle of texts to be read or chanted at liturgical services on particular weeks and movable feasts throughout the year; a book that contains this cycle.

description: Borrowed from Spanish temporal (“storm”), perhaps via back-formation from the plural temporales.

entries.meaning: (meteorology) A rainy wind that blows into Central America from the southwest during the summer, often bringing stormy weather.
